clinical_study.brief_title: Predicting Success of HFNC: The Utility of the ROX Index
clinical_study.official_title: Predicting Failure of High Flow Nasal Cannula in Pneumonia Patients With Hypoxemic Respiratory Failure: The Utility of ROX Index

lead_sponsor.agency: Hospital Universitari Vall d'Hebron Research Institute

clinical_study.source: Hospital Universitari Vall d'Hebron Research Institute

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of the study was to describe early predictors and to develop a prediction tool that accurately identifies the need for mechanical ventilation in pneumonia patients with acute respiratory failure treated with High Flow nasal cannula.

detailed_description.textblock:
Purpose The purpose of the study is to describe early predictors and to develop a prediction tool that accurately identifies the need for mechanical ventilation (MV) in pneumonia patients with hypoxemic acute respiratory failure (ARF) treated with high-flow nasal cannula (HFNC).
Materials and methods This is a 4-year prospective observational 2-center cohort study including patients with severe pneumonia treated with HFNC. High-flow nasal cannula failure was defined as need for MV. ROX index was defined as the ratio of pulse oximetry/fraction of inspired oxygen to respiratory rate.

primary_outcome.measure: prediction of need for mechanical ventilation using ROX index
primary_outcome.time_frame: through study completion, an average of 1 year
primary_outcome.description: participants will be followed during their stay in the ICU registering the days with HFNC treatment and their need or not for mechanical ventilation.

arm_group.description: HFNC with no need for mechanical ventilation
HFNC with need for mechanical ventilation

study_pop.textblock: patients with acute respiratory failure admitted to intensive care unit receiving high-flow nasal cannula treatment.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- diagnosis of acute respiratory failure secondary to pneumonia receiving HFNC therapy
Exclusion Criteria:
- younger than 18 years old
- indication for mechanical ventilation at ICU admission
- limitation of therapeutic effort
